entry.title: Re: How can I retrieve through the Service Layer the quan...
entry.content:
Hi @RonaldoCJunior ,

I don't think that the Service Layer natively provides a direct endpoint to retrieve batch quantities distributed per warehouse.

In those cases, I simply create a view, fetching data from the batch/warehouse tables, ending with B1SLQuery (i.e., MyWhsBatchB1SLQuery), and expose it via the following endpoint:

POST https://<server>:50000/b1s/v2/SQLViews('<view name>')/Expose

Then I call it using:

GET https://<server>:50000/b1s/v2/view.svc/<view name>

Have a look at the SAP's official documentation: SQL View Exposure | SAP Help Portal

I hope it helps.

BR,
Felipe

entry.title: How to update multiple entities in a single OData $batch request.
entry.content:
• I am sending one  $batch request with multipart/mixed format.

  • Inside, you created one changeset with 3 PATCH requests.

  • SAP will execute all 3 updates together.

  • If one fails (e.g. invalid IBAN), the whole changeset is rolled back.

 

 

--batch_001
Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary=changeset_001

--changeset_001
Content-Type: application/http
Content-Transfer-Encoding: binary

PATCH A_BusinessPartner('XXXX') HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/json

{
"BusinessPartnerCategory": "X",
"BusinessPartnerGrouping": "XXXX"
}
--changeset_001
Content-Type: application/http
Content-Transfer-Encoding: binary

PATCH A_BusinessPartnerAddress(BusinessPartner='XXXX',AddressID='XXX') HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/json

{
"CityName": "Dubai",
"PostalCode": "00000"
}
--changeset_001
Content-Type: application/http
Content-Transfer-Encoding: binary

PATCH A_BusinessPartnerBank(BusinessPartner='XXXX',BankIdentification='XXXX') HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/json

{
"BankName": "XXXXXXXXX",
"IBAN": "XXXXXXXXXXX"
}

--changeset_001--
--batch_001--

entry.title: Solution Documentation with Pictures: A Practical Guide for SAP Signavio
entry.content:
High-quality process documentation goes beyond text. In SAP Signavio, you can enrich your processes by uploading documents and pictures directly into the file storage and linking them to your diagrams. This makes your process models more tangible, supports knowledge transfer, and ensures that all stakeholders have the same visual understanding.

Recently, one of our customers who was manually documenting their solutions in SAP Cloud ALM approached us  with the question: Can this be automated in SAP Signavio or at least partially automated  

This real-world scenario inspired us to first outline the customer’s current approach and then explore how SAP Signavio can be leveraged to make documentation more efficient and effective.

In this guide, we will walk you through the step-by-step process of uploading images into SAP Signavio, linking them to your processes, and even generating reports that include these visuals. Along the way, we’ll highlight important considerations such as file size limits, storage quotas, and best practices for hosting images to avoid broken links.

By the end, you’ll be able to create more engaging and efficient documentation and see how SAP Signavio can help transform manual work into smarter, collaborative process documentation.

Step 1) Think about what should be included in your Solution Documentation and create a reporting template. SAP Signavio provides a template for process documentation, but you may also want to design your own. Deep dive HERE

Create a new Template

Step 2) In our scenario, I want to include one screenshot for each task in the process to show where the activity takes place within the respective application. For example, the task “Create goods receipt”.

This task takes place in an SAP S/4HANA system. To add the corresponding screenshot, we select the task and navigate to “Documentation.”

There, the screenshot is inserted. Please note that there is a disclaimer at the end of the blog post regarding the upload and use of images, where we explain the applicable limitations and requirements.

 

After the upload, you also have the option to adjust the image to the correct size.

Nach dem Upload besteht auch die Option das Bild auf die korrekte Größe anzupassen.

Step 3) Generate the report. Go to the Process Manager and automatically generate your Solution Documentation.

Make sure that you have selected your template.

Pick the Process where you want to generate a report and click “Generate documentation”. 

 

After a few moments you have a PDF ready to use.

When you open the PDF, you see at the task “Create goods receipt” this. The information’s around the picture/screenshot are based on the attributes in Signavio so the quality depend on how good you are maintain your processes in Signavio.

You can add your screenshots also on different other ways like the dictionary or an own attribute.

 

Disclaimer

Please note the following limitations when working with images in SAP Signavio documentation:

  • Images that are not accessible to all users may appear as broken links if the necessary permissions or log-ins are missing.

  • To avoid this, we recommend embedding images only as:

    • Unlisted images (with hidden names and implicit authentication tokens, HTTPS only), e.g.
      https://external.domain.com/files/hidden-file-name-nobody-guesses?possibleToken=123nekot321

    • Publicly hosted images (without access or authentication restrictions, HTTPS only), e.g.
      https://external.domain.com/files/my_image.png

  • Be aware that externally hosted images may potentially be accessed by third parties.

If you want to use more images than 10GB you can also create the report as an word file and add the images via copy paste. This is not a super good alternativ, but then you have a standard report and only the work of adding the pictures manually. When you read the intro again you see that we are coming from a use case where you have 100% manual work.  

  • Storage limits also apply:

    • Maximum available storage: 10 GB

    • Maximum single file size: 32 MB

    • Only HTTPS links are supported for external images 

Alternativ Step "4" Workaround with the Word File
If you want more flexibility in editing your Solution Documentation, you can export the generated report to a Word file. This allows you to adjust formatting, add further explanations, or insert screenshots and graphics that go beyond the default template. Once finished, the document can be shared with stakeholders or uploaded again into the SAP Signavio file storage for central access.

Summary & Outlook

In this use case, our customer currently documents solutions for SAP Cloud ALM manually, including the collection of screenshots and descriptions for each process task. While this approach works, it requires significant manual effort, is prone to errors, and makes it difficult to maintain a consistent documentation standard across teams.

By leveraging SAP Signavio, documentation can be streamlined and partially automated. Screenshots and supporting documents can be uploaded directly into the file storage, linked to process tasks, and included automatically in generated reports. With the right reporting template, organizations ensure a consistent structure while reducing repetitive work.

Our solution can take this even further by exploring automation options — for example, integrating with SAP S/4HANA to capture screenshots or system steps automatically, or pre-populating process documentation fields through standardized templates. This reduces manual overhead, improves quality, and enables scalable, audit-ready documentation.

In short, we can help transform documentation from a manual, error-prone task into a smart, collaborative, and partially automated process powered by SAP Signavio.

entry.title: Re: Differences in planed cost of raw materials between c...
entry.content:
Yes you are correct. The planned cost in a production order is derived from the Valuation price of the raw material at the time the order is created. This valuation price can either be Standard Price or Moving Average Price. In your case, the raw material has a moving average price of 1801 JPY. But the Purchasing Info Record is not used directly in production order costing which is 1800 JPY. Therefore, the production order picked up 1801 JPY, leading to a total of 180100 JPY for 10 units of ZFG004.

If you want cost estimates and production orders to align, consider:

  • Switching raw material to Standard Price (S) or
  • configure your costing variant to use MAP instead of PIR.

This ensures consistency across planning and execution.

We’re super excited to kick off the SAP Community Group in Nigeria, a space created for collaboration, learning, and innovation within our local SAP ecosystem. Whether you’re a seasoned SAP professional, just starting out, or a business leader using SAP solutions to make an impact, this community is for you. entry.title: Introducing Buildless Mode in the Kyma Serverless Module
entry.content:
Kyma Serverless is evolving! We have just rolled out a new version of the Serverless module (1.8.2) with a new opt-in feature called buildless mode.
We invite you to try it out, as it allows you to experience faster, simpler, and more secure serverless development. Here’s why you should give it a try.

 

Faster Function Startup

Functions start much quicker! This means you can iterate faster, reducing the time between writing code and seeing it run. While dependency resolution now happens at Pod startup, the expensive image build step is gone. Our tests show that a simple Function with one dependency is ready in about 10 seconds.

 

Preserving Resources

No More In-Cluster Docker Builds

Function container images are no longer built inside the Kyma environment, saving significant computational resources. Docker builds are typically resource-intensive, and eliminating them frees up your cluster for what matters most—running your workloads.

No Need to Store Function Images

Buildless mode removes the requirement for an external Docker registry. If you previously used an in-cluster registry, you’ll also save on storage resources, as Function images are no longer stored anywhere.

 

Enhanced Security

Without build jobs, Functions can run in namespaces with more restrictive Pod security levels, making your workloads safer by default.

 

How Does It Work?

Kyma provides ready-to-use Function runtime images with dedicated mount points for your custom logic and dependencies. When a Function Pod starts:

  • your dependencies are resolved and mounted at startup,

  • your custom Function code is also mounted into the serving framework at startup.

This means your code and dependencies are injected directly into the running environment, skipping the build and push steps entirely.

 

More Outcomes and Considerations

Deprecated Fields

All fields deprecated in the Serverless 1.6.0 release are no longer functional in buildless mode. For the full list of deprecated fields, See the Serverless 1.8.0 What's New note.

Scaling

Buildless mode does not support autoscaling based on CPU consumption out of the box. However, since the Function CRD supports the `/scale` subresource, you can still scale your Functions using your own HPAs or leverage KEDA’s ScaledObject API for advanced, event-driven scaling strategies. To learn how to scale your Functions using external scalers, see the Use External Scalers tutorial.

 

How to Enable Buildless Mode


Enabling buildless mode is simple!
Just add the following annotation to your Serverless custom resource:

 
serverless.kyma-project.io/buildless-mode: "enabled"

You can do this via Kyma Dashboard or with kubectl. If you want to switch back, simply remove the annotation. For more information, see Configuring Serverless.

 

What’s Next?

Currently (v1.8): Buildless mode is opt-in. Try it out and share your feedback!
Coming Soon (v1.9): We plan to make buildless mode the default mode, with an option to opt out if needed.
Future (v2.0): Our ultimate goal is to go fully buildless for all Kyma Serverless workloads.
Give buildless mode a try today and experience a faster, simpler, and more secure way to run Serverless Functions in Kyma!

 
For more information, see Serverless Buildless Mode.

entry.title: Re: TM Public Cloud - Transportation cockpit enhancement...
entry.content:
Hi @zsoci 

Thank you for your question.

You do not have the possibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud by using standard configuration to enhance the field catalog in the Transportation Cockpit. That means the standard configuration will not enable you add custom fields from Sales order. The public cloud version currently restricts cockpit enhancements and UI adaptations for the Transportation Cockpit. Public Cloud provides flexible adaptation either through in-app extensibility or by adapting through UI for some apps but not for TM Cockpit.

The on-premise solution, however, does offer those enhancement features. Which allow you to customise the cockpit to suit your layout ID config desires.

You can consider either raising an SAP Customer Influence Request if this feature is critical for your operations or using Reporting Apps to leveraging embedded analytics, custom reports or OData outbound to enable you display this data somewhere else.

Consult the links below for more details.

Transportation Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition 2308

Equipment Categories in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Define Field Catalogs for Transportation Cockpit

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: why control keys 0052 and 0053 shall contain indicato...
entry.content: For information, the purpose of Control Key 0052 is integration of Outbound Deliveries from Sales Orders while 0053 from Stock Transport Orders (STO) or other logistics processes. In short, 0052 is related to Sales and 0053 is related to MM. Having said this, by checking Outbound Delivery in both you ensure TM picks up all relevant delivery documents, regardless of their source, TM can create Freight Units and Freight Orders for both sales and logistics flows. You avoid missing documents that might otherwise be excluded from planning.

entry.title: Re: MRP not considering batch length Correctly
entry.content:
You can solve the planning mismatch by enabling batch-level tracking and selection rules. These are standard features and do not require custom development. If you later need MRP to plan based on usable tube pieces, you can explore phantom materials or extensions, but that’s optional.

So explore Batch Management with Characteristics. Activate Batch Management for the tube material. Define a Batch Characteristic for Length like CHAR_LENGTH. Assign it to a Batch Class and link it to the material. This allows each tube to carry its actual length as metadata. See that your material is set to batch-specific inventory. This lets SAP track stock per batch, not just total meters.

Define batch selection rules in the BOM or routing. Use a selection class with a rule like CHAR_LENGTH ≥ 4m. This ensures only batches with sufficient length are considered during production. Note, this affects batch determination during production, not MRP directly.

entry.title: Managing Agricultural WIP Using WBS and Project Stock Consumption in SAP
entry.content:
In Arable production project,  we want to use WBS element to collect both direct expenses (labor, services, etc.) and expenses from the consumption of materials received into project stock (e.g., seeds, fertilizers). 

And we want the cost of consumption of those materials (e.g., via movement type 201 in MIGO) to be posted to the WBS and included in Results Analysis (RA) for WIP capitalization along side with the direct expenses.

The goal is to exclude from the P&L the costs occured from the consumption of those materials and have them instead on WIP account.

My questions are: 

1. How to include the costs occured from the consumption of materials using MIGO 201 movement type into the actual costs of that WBS? 

2. Is this the correct approach for agricultural WIP tracking in SAP in the absence of a PP module?

Any insights or recommendations from your experience would be greatly appreciated!

PLM Project System (PS); FIN Cost Object Controlling ; SAP Revenue Accounting and Reporting

entry.title: Re: Not able to edit Purchase requisition due to In Proce...
entry.content:
System would trigger this error message MMPUR_REQ_COMMON132 if the Purchase Requisition (PR) item is locked due to external processing status. Specifically, the item is either possibly sent to an external procurement system (like Ariba or SRM) or rejected in the external system but not yet updated in S/4HANA. This status prevents editing or deletion of the PR item in S/4HANA, even if you try via ME52N or ME54N. Also, the program RLORD035 is designed to correct inconsistencies between planned orders and purchase requisitions, but it does not reset external processing flags or statuses. That is why it didn’t help in your case.

If your system is integrated with Ariba or SRM, check whether the PRs were Sent to the external system, Rejected or failed there and not properly updated back in S/4HANA. Go to me53n, input that PR and execute. Check what status is there in the "Status" tab. If Ariba is integrated, you can ask your middleware team to resend the rejection confirmation or cancel the external process. This may unlock the PR for deletion.

Finally, and importantly, SAP does not provide a standard transaction to reset this status. You will need a custom report or enhancement to reset the external status flags or use BAdI MMPUR_REQUISITION_CUST to override status logic. Needless to mention, this should be done carefully, only if you’re sure the PR is no longer needed or valid.

In SAP Document AI (Premium version), I run into a limitation when invoices or other documents contain line items that are split across two pages.

entry.title: Re: CDS for Business Partner International address version
entry.content:
As I know, the standard CDS views like I_Address or I_Address_2 are designed to return only the default address version (ADCP.NATION = ' '). So, International/local versions are not exposed there on purpose.

If you need both, you may have to check this two options:
- use the released API entity A_BPIntlAddressVersion and join it with the BP address, this will give you default and local versions.
- or build your own CDS view on ADRC/ADCP with ADDRESS_ID and NATION, so you can fetch the local version where NATION <> ' '.

entry.title: Re: Managing Agricultural WIP Using WBS and Project Stock...
entry.content:
If your requirement is to posts the material consumption via movement type 201 to the WBS element and is included in Results Analysis (RA), follow these steps:

With Special Stock Q, when you procure materials like seeds or fertilizers, assign the WBS element in the purchase requisition or PO. This ensures the goods receipt goes into project stock (stock type Q).

During MIGO, use movement type 201 or 221 if applicable, and enter the WBS element in the account assignment. This posts the material consumption directly to the WBS as an actual cost.

Then comes to correct Valuation Class for these materials. Ensure, material master have a valuation class that maps to the correct cost element in OBYC for the transaction keys like GBB-VBR. This ensures the posting hits the right cost element for RA.

Finally, configure RA to include actual costs from material consumption in KKA2 & KKA3. Use RA version that includes cost elements from both direct expenses and material consumption. By doing so, the outcome would be the cost of consumed materials will be posted to the WBS and capitalized as WIP, not expensed to P&L.

entry.title: Re: Launching My Custom SAPUI5 App in S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hey everyone,

I was able to find a way to create the launchpad exactly how I needed it. I apologize if my original question wasn't clear, but my main goal was to create a transportable launchpad object.

The standard way of creating launchpads directly within the S/4HANA apps would have required me to recreate the object in every environment. While the static URL wasn't a major issue, the creation process itself was a bit frustrating. The objects created this way used the prefix YY1 and the suffix CAP, and my objects was developed in RAP (ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model).

The correct approach, which I found using ADT (ABAP Development Tools), is to use objects of the type "Fiori User Interface". Here's the correct workflow:

First, you need to create a Launchpad Space Templates object.

Inside the space, you'll create one or more Launchpad Page Templates.

Within these pages, you will add the apps using Launchpad App Descriptor Items. It's important to note that each app must be associated with an item in IAM (Identity and Access Management) Apps.

Finally, you need to create a role template. This is done inside the Identity and Access Management object type. First, you create the Business Role Template and then associate it with the Launchpad Space Template using Business Role Templ. - Launchpad Space Templ. Assignments.

All of these steps are covered in this excellent SAP tutorial: https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-environment-create-spaces-pages-template.html

Hope this helps anyone facing the same challenge!

Kind Regards,

Marcelo Romeiro

entry.title: Set up SAP PI Integration Builder using open-source Java and OpenWebStart
entry.content:
Some general remarks before starting

A. There are 3 How-To sections - for Ubuntu Desktop, for MacBook, and for Windows. You can scroll down to the relevant section according to your OS preference.

B. There is also - if you prefer - this SAP Note:

https://me.sap.com/notes/2677849

...which advises to use OpenWebStart with sapjvm 8... this advice is of limited use for me personally, since for my own preferred OS choices - modern MacBooks (M1, M2, ...) using arm64 architecture, and arm64 Linux Desktop distros - I haven't seen any arm64-based sapjvm 8 JDKs available for download.  

If you want to download a sapjvm 8, then here is one location (maintained by SAP):

https://tools.hana.ondemand.com/#cloud

In this blog we don't consider this sapjvm option.

C. For Windows, I have also tested successfully with a different variant of openJDK 8 - Eclipse Adoptium 8 - so feel free to try that instead of Azul JDK in the Windows case. For macOS and Linux, Eclipse Adoptium probably only working in x64-architecture cases (for MacBooks that means you need to have an old "Intel" MacBook)... anyway here is the link to Eclipse Adoptium openJDK 8: https://adoptium.net/en-GB/temurin/releases?version=8&os=any&arch=any

D. There is no Helpdesk for this blog, so if you get stuck trying to follow the advice, I am just wishing you good luck in using your own computing skills to get unstuck 🙂

 

Intro

In an SAP PI (Process Integration) system, it is possible to build new integration content – don’t ask me for the details, I have never done any of this PI content-work and never will 😂. Anyway the tool that is offered for this work is called the SAP PI Integration Builder, so when we logon to a PI system we see it there as one of the main options on the landing page:

<http(s):>//<your.pi.hostname>:<portnumber>/dir/start/index.jsp

When you click the link available from hovering the mouse over the text “Integration Builder”... well, what happens nowadays, is that the browser downloads the .jnlp file, and... that is all:

Yes, it says in the browser that JavaWebStart is starting, but it isn't starting and it cannot even start, because such an app typically does not exist on your machine or on your VM, for the simple reason that you don't typically have a working JDK 8 on your machine.

Anyway, if we look at the contents of the directory.jnlp contents, here is some relevant info:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><jnlp spec="1.0+" codebase="<http(s):>//<your.pi.hostname>:<portnumber>/dir/">

[Tells us where the jars are going to be downloaded from, is a reasonable guess].

<application-desc main-class="com.sap.aii.ibdir.gui.appl.ApplicationImpl">
<argument>webstart</argument>
</application-desc>

[Tells us the main class – in Java world, the “start-point” – for getting the whole Integration Builder up and running].

So now our task is to work out how to use the open-source replacement for JavaWebStart, which is called OpenWebStart:

https://openwebstart.com/

...with a suitable open-source JVM (in/via JRE or JDK), so that people can use the PI Integration Builder. Note that this will need to be a JVM 8, as more recent major versions do not generally contain any javaws utility.

We start with Linux, because a Linux VM is a safe place to make mistakes. After that, we solve for macOS, because ahm a MacBook user maself. And then we solve for Windows, which I last used Java on, hmm, in 2015 maybe, but solved it for the PI case anyway (turned out to be easiest case of these three).

 

Demo on Xubuntu Desktop (Linux)

Although we say “Solution for Linux”, the OpenWebStart site offers only a .deb package for Ubuntu-based distros (may or may not work on other Debian-based desktops). Also, since this OpenWebStart is meant to be GUI-based, we can assume that Ubuntu-based Desktop distros, is the scope. Xubuntu Desktop is such a distro. (My assumption is that sudo-rights are needed, but did not test without sudo so that is just an assumption). If you are using some other distro, well, good luck - generally what works on Xubuntu, works on Ubuntu, that is all I can predict for this Integration Builder case.

 

Ubuntu: Get OpenWebStart

Download the .deb package from here:

https://openwebstart.com/download/

Open a Terminal and navigate to the directory you downloaded the .deb package to. Then install the app from the .deb package, for example:

sudo dpkg -i OpenWebStart_linux_1_11_0.deb

 

Ubuntu: Get OpenJDK 8

Next, we need an older version of OpenJDK for Linux (current version on ma' Xubuntu is 11, we need version 8):

sudo apt install openjdk-8-jdk

You can check which JDKs you have available using:

update-java-alternatives --list

If you like (though it’s irrelevant actually, as OpenWebStart decides via its own Settings config, not via reference to default JDK), you can set the machine to use some specific JDK, using sudo and the -s option:

sudo update-java-alternatives -s java-1.8.0-openjdk-arm64

 

Next step is related to, let’s not call it a bug, to a feature of OpenJDK, that many Java GUI apps will fail to open if they don’t find a file called javafx.properties in the JRE/JDK that is running the app – examples include “OpenWebStart Settings”-app, as well as “SAPGUI for Java for Linux”-app. But don’t worry, this is fixable just by creating an (empty) file called javafx.properties in the appropriate location: in our case where we have two JDKs, then the relevant directories are these or similar to these:

/usr/lib/jvm/java-11-openjdk-arm64/lib

/usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-arm64/jre/lib 

So to solve this, create the relevant (empty) file in those directories:

sudo touch /usr/lib/jvm/java-11-openjdk-arm64/lib/javafx.properties

sudo touch /usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-arm64/jre/lib/javafx.properties

 

Ubuntu: Link OpenJDK 8 to OpenWebStart

Now we can open the GUI app “OpenWebStart Settings”, and go to the JVM Manager tab, and then Add Local... navigate to the relevant JDK, Open. You can remove any other JVMs (typically OpenWebStart has already downloaded its preferred JVM called Eclipse Adoptium, but at least on my arm64 VM this x64 JVM is not going to work (tested), and anyway we are using the OpenJDK 8 that we installed above). Then press Apply to save the changes, and if you like press OK to close the Settings app.

 

I also recommend going into the JVM Manager -> Settings and changing to option “Do Not Download any version” [of Adoptium JVM], since we won’t be able to run Integration Builder with that JVM.

 

Ubuntu: Run Integration Builder

Now we can go to the PI system and click on the link to download the .jnlp:

<http(s):>//<your.pi.hostname>:<portnumber>/dir/start/index.jsp

Ignore the false messaging about non-existent JavaWebStart starting. Instead we go to the folder that contains the downloaded directory.jnlp file, then right-click and choose “Open With” and choose “OpenWebStart” (or, you can go to “Set Default Application...” and then set OpenWebStart as the default, and then you can open with double-click): 

If OpenWebStart offers to download an update of its preferred JVM, I suggest clicking No, as it will then prevent Integration Builder from being run if used.

Then BANZAI!! ... the Java app called SAP Integration Builder opens and runs ok:

 

Demo on MacBook M1 Pro

We assume that in 2025 everyone is using an arm64 MacBook (“M-series”). At demo time I had an M1 MacBook at work, since then upgraded to M4 and tested that the instructions work just as well on the newer machine.

[Also I have assumed that the MacBook user has sudo (admin) rights... if you are a developer, it’s generally needed – but good luck if someone wants to try without admin rights; and good luck if you have an old Intel MacBook – in that case, you would want to use x64 packages and apps, not aarch64/arm64 ones].

 

macOS: Get OpenWebStart

Download the .dmg installer from here:

https://openwebstart.com/download/

So aarch64 means arm64 means our M1 MacBook, so we choose the relevant dmg. Open it and click on the button lower-middle of screen to start the installer:

Because I have sudo rights on the MacBook, even if I choose “Install for current user” the App contents are installed in /Applications i.e. system-wide, I assume it’s the same location if installing for all users of the MacBook, but not tested. Anyway the result of installing successfully for me is: 

We can open “OpenWebStart Settings” and it runs ok, but let’s close it again (by pressing OK in bottom menu) as we still need to do the next step, which is to install OpenJDK 8...

 

macOS: Get OpenJDK 8 for aarch64/arm64

Usually for MacBook, when we want some specific OpenJDK version, we would go to:

https://adoptium.net/en-GB/temurin/archive/

... and choose Version “8 – LTS” (Long-Term Stable). But the problem here is that for M-series MacBooks, which were launched in 2020, this was after Java 8 had already been sidelined by a more recent major version – so it seems there isn’t any Eclipse Adoptium OpenJDK 8 for macOS on aarch64/arm64 architecture...

Another common method for installing Java on macOS is to use Homebrew, though actually this won’t help us either. (If you don’t already have Homebrew, instructions on installing it are here: https://brew.sh/  ). So this approach doesn’t work for OpenJDK 8:

brew install openjdk@8

[...] openjdk@8: The x86_64 architecture is required for this software.

Error: openjdk@8: An unsatisfied requirement failed this build.

Also checked whether SapMachine (SAP’s version of OpenJDK: https://sap.github.io/SapMachine/ ) has a SapMachine 8 available for macOS – nope, not available. And even downloaded from SAP tools the x64 sapjvm_8 JDK, and tested that it doesn’t work either for the PI Integration Builder case.

So the solution which actually works... is to use a certified, free to use OpenJDK 8 for arm64 macOS from Azul systems.

https://www.azul.com/downloads/?package=jdk#zulu

Scroll down to the filters and enter the relevant data, which corresponds to this URL:

https://www.azul.com/downloads/?version=java-8-lts&os=macos&architecture=arm-64-bit&package=jdk#zulu

Actually let’s download the .zip archive, might be easier to use. Done. Then unzip if needed, and move the whole set of folders and files to somewhere logical, for example I put the stuff in /Users/dylan.drummond/java-generic/ directory (you would obviously use a different directory).

 

macOS: Link OpenJDK 8 to OpenWebStart

Now we can open the “OpenWebStart Settings”-app again. In the tab JVM Manager, delete any “non-OpenJDK 8” or non-arm64 JVMs. Then Add Local... for example I specified:

/Users/dylan.drummond/java-generic/zulu8.84.0.15-ca-jdk8.0.442-macosx_aarch64/zulu8.jdk/Contents/Home

For some reason 2 JREs added from path...Contents/Home:

We can leave them both there. I also recommend going into the JVM Manager -> Settings and changing to option Do Not Download [Adoptium JVM], since we won’t be able to run Integration Builder with any version of that JVM (since there isn't an arm64 JDK 8 version).

Next step is to test if this works...

 

macOS: Run Integration Builder

Go to the PI system and click on the Integration Builder link to download the .jnlp:

<http(s):>//<your.pi.hostname>:<portnumber>/dir/start/index.jsp

Ignore the false message about Java Web Start starting. Instead in Finder we right-click on the downloaded directory.jnlp file, ignore the default suggestion (JavaLauncher) and choose Open With... Other... add “OpenWebStart javaws”:

(You can also check the box “Always Open With” to set “OpenWebStart javaws” as the default app to open .jnlp files – that is what I did later as it saves from having to use “Open With” every time). Then we open the file... however, it might not actually open yet, for example I get the error message:

We have no reason to suspect that a file supplied from an SAP system, used to run an SAP product, would have any malware, so here is the procedure to override this warning... Click on the Question-mark icon highlighted in magenta in the above screenshot. Then click on the link “Open an app by overriding security settings”. From the next screen, click on the link “Open Privacy & Security Settings for me”. Scroll down to Security section and click on the button “Open Anyway” next to the reference to the jnlp file:

Then you do is go back to the popup that said about the error, and click Done. Then open the directory.jnlp file again, this time you get a different popup, and this time you have the option “Open Anyway”:

You might get asked if you want to download latest version of (Adoptium) JVM (if you didn’t turn off that behaviour in Settings app), I clicked No as that JVM favoured by OpenWebStart is not what we want to use - recommend you do the same.

Finally we get one more popup, we click Open:

Now the Java program starts, but before we can get to the main screen of the SAP Integration Builder, still a couple of steps... the first is to accept the SAP SE certificate from the popup – keep “Always trust content from this publisher” checked, and click Run:

Then, because it seems there isn’t an SSO logon over Java available, you need to logon to the PI system using your SAP User ID and password:

...so we logon, and... BANZAI!!

 

Demo on Windows 11 (works also on Windows 10)

This demo was done on a Windows 11 VM, where I have admin rights to the local machine. This also worked ok on a Windows 10 machine for a user with no local admin rights (i.e. a standard user).

 

Win11: Get OpenWebStart

[Demo VM is actually running arm64 Windows Insider build, but this should be able to run all the x64 stuff via JIT emulation, so we only consider x64 packages].

Download the x64 .exe installer from here:

https://openwebstart.com/download/

I installed OpenWebStart using the default options, including “For current user only”.

 

Win11: Get OpenJDK 8

Seems that there is no Microsoft Build of OpenJDK 8 (in January 2025 I found only versions going back to OpenJDK 11), but no problem, we can get a useful and certified OpenJDK 8 from Azul:

https://www.azul.com/downloads/?package=jdk#zulu

Enter the relevant parameters:

https://www.azul.com/downloads/?version=java-8-lts&os=windows&architecture=x86-64-bit&package=jdk#zulu

Download the .zip version from the Download button options. Unzip it and then copy the set of folders and files to some useful location, for example I put the stuff in C:\Users\marmot\Documents\ folder. 

 

Win11: Link OpenJDK 8 to OpenWebStart

Open OpenWebStart Settings app, from wherever you installed it or using the Search box: 

In the app, go to JVM Manager section. From there, go to Settings button and set Update Strategy to “Do not download any version”, as we don’t want the JVM that OpenWebStart prefers to use, in fact it prevents us from running SAP Integration Builder, so just change the Settings like ah suggested.

Then in JVM Manager section, use “Add local..” button and point it to the OpenJDK folder, in the demo example the path is: C:\Users\marmot\Documents\zulu8.84.0.15-ca-jdk8.0.442-win_x64 ...2 items are added, we can keep them both, then press Apply to save those changes:

 

Win11: Run Integration Builder

Go to the PI system and click on the Integration Builder link to download the .jnlp:

<http(s):>//<your.pi.hostname>:<portnumber>/dir/start/index.jsp

Ignore the false message about Java Web Start starting. If you get a warning for directory.jnlp about “Insecure download blocked”, recall that this file is coming from your organisation's SAP system, so you should trust it, so you press “Keep” to complete the download.

Then open the directory.jnlp file – when installing OpenWebStart, you should have already chosen in that installation workflow to associate .jnlp files to OpenWebStart, but if not, then you can use “Open With” and choose that  “Launcher for .jnlp applications according to JSR 56”, which should be the OpenWebStart app unless you have other such JavaWebStart replacement apps installed.

There might be a few seconds delay after opening before you get a popup showing progress of the downloads that directory.jnlp invokes, and then you get the security popup, ah suggest keeping checked the option “Always trust content from this publisher” as it is SAP SE, and you probably don’t want to have this popup every time – anyway then press Run:

Depending on your computer’s security settings, you might get asked if you want to allow access to the Zulu (Azul) OpenJDK “app” from public and private networks:

I chose Allow, since after all the data and content handled by the local Integration Builder is mainly located on the SAP PI server which is on the SOK network. Anyway the Integration Builder is now opened, Q.E.D. 

Note that at some point in the process of starting the app, you may be asked to logon to the relevant SAP PI system (e.g. if SSO does not work), then obviously in that case you would need to do a manual logon using your SAP User ID and password.

entry.title: Re: is the a transaction where I can get the value of mhd...
entry.content:
Instead of parsing the DESADV IDoc line-by-line, you can retrieve the MHDRZ (Shelf Life Expiration Date Rule) from the delivery document using standard transaction via VL03N. There, navigate to Item → Batch → Shelf Life Data Or Item → Additional Data → Expiration Date Rule (MHDRZ) if available. This shows the life rule applied at the time of delivery creation.

Having said that, when SAP sends a DESADV IDoc to a 3PL, it pulls data directly from the outbound delivery document. That means the MHDRZ value used in the IDoc is the same one stored in the delivery. You don’t need to parse the IDoc to find MHDRZ, you can just check the delivery document itself.

entry.title: Journaling for Resilience in the Corporate Context
entry.content:
In today’s fast-paced corporate world, stress, overwhelm, and even burnout can easily creep into our day-to-day lives. While organizations are increasingly investing in well-being initiatives, there is one simple, low-cost, and highly effective tool that is often overlooked: journaling.

Why Journaling?

Journaling is more than simply “keeping a diary.” It’s a structured way to pause, reflect, and create mental space. Research shows that regular expressive writing can:

  • Reduce stress and support emotional regulation
  • Strengthen resilience by helping us process challenges more constructively
  • Boost clarity, creativity, and problem-solving
  • Foster a sense of agency and self-awareness

In the context of burnout prevention, journaling acts as a buffer: instead of suppressing emotions or letting them spiral, we can capture them on paper and view them from a safer distance. This shift often reduces overwhelm and opens up new perspectives.

Journaling in the Workplace

At SAP, we are exploring how journaling can be integrated into our culture of well-being and resilience. Journaling sessions provide employees with a structured time-out from the noise of daily tasks—creating room to reflect, reset, and recharge. They can be facilitated virtually or on-site and require nothing more than a pen and paper.

How to Structure a 30-Minute Journaling Session

A short, guided journaling session can already have a big impact. Here’s a simple structure you can use:

  1. Arrive (1 minute)
    A short moment to pause, close the eyes, and take a breath. This helps participants shift from “doing mode” into “being mode.”
  2. Introduction (2 minutes)
    Briefly explain how journaling works and share the benefits. Emphasize that it’s not about writing beautifully or perfectly—it’s about honesty, curiosity, and self-reflection.
  3. Guided Prompts (15 minutes)
    Offer 3–4 journaling prompts. Give participants about 3 minutes per prompt to write freely, without overthinking. Invite mini breaks in between the prompts, such as taking three conscious breaths, looking around for a moment, or simply shaking your hands.
    Example prompts could be: “Right now, I feel…”, “One thing that is taking a lot of my energy is…”, “A small step I could take to support myself this week is…”, “What am I grateful for today?”
  4. Reflection (3 minutes)
    Invite participants to read through what they wrote. They don’t need to edit or judge, just notice what stands out.
  5. Optional Sharing (5–7 minutes)
    Create an open space where participants can (if they wish) share insights, discoveries, or surprises. Listening is just as valuable as sharing.

Why It Works

This simple practice helps employees reconnect with themselves, recognize stress patterns early, and uncover inner resources for resilience. Over time, journaling builds a habit of pausing and reflecting, which translates into greater well-being and better stress management.

A Gentle Invitation

If you’re curious, try journaling for yourself—or bring a short session into your team. All it takes is 30 minutes, a pen, and some openness. The benefits for clarity, resilience, and burnout prevention can be surprisingly profound.

Have you tried journaling at work—or would you be interested in joining a guided session? Share your thoughts in the comments.

Would you like me to also draft a set of ready-to-use journaling prompts tailored for corporate teams (e.g., resilience, teamwork, stress release)?

entry.title: Multiple asset transfer between company's branches/divisions
entry.content: Hi. Our team is implementing SAP ERP for a bank. The system is SAP S/4HANA 2023 om-premise. There are several branches and other divisions within the bank. When we want to do an asset transfer from one branch/division to another one (from one cost center to another one), we need a financial posting to be able to calculate spendings and to make a balance for each branch. Each branch is a separate profit center and a separate cost center, while divisions in Head Office have one profit center but separate cost centers. We found <Intracompany asset transfer> application to proceed with the transfer. Do I understand right, that in this case this is the best suitable application for registering asset movement? When we make a single asset transfer the sending asset is credited and the receiving asset is debited, but I can't find the underlying transactions: I understood that the sending asset should be credited, a clearing account of the appropriate cost center/profit center should be debited, then the clearing account should be credited and then the receiving asset should be debited. Am I wrong? Besides, could you please suggest if there is an opportunity to transfer asset to a new one in case of multiple asset transfer? Thank you in advance for your experienced answers and time spent.
